answers.author: Joseph Land
answers.text:
Hallie--
For what it's worth.  I worked for a municipality which had an extremely thorough street sweeping program and catch basin inspection process.  We never inspected compliance on the residential side unless the ground was opened up in the right of way where downspouts were located, or if there were known issues/complaints causing the work order in the first place.  It sounds as if this would require a lot of resources for a larger city such as San Diego, however it may save a lot of headaches down the road.
Seth

answers.author: Jesse Himes
answers.text:
Hi Hallie,
Great question! I found a couple of things on the Knowledge Network that may be good resources for you.
There is a topic area in the Knowledge Network devoted to sustainability and it includes articles and blogs related to pollution prevention.
http://icma.org/en/icma/knowledge_network/topics/kn/Topic/253/Sustainability
I also found a couple of case studies. This one looks at storm-water in Lake County, Illinois. 
https://icma.org/Documents/Document/Document/303251
And this one is about household hazardous materials and how they can cause pollution.
https://icma.org/Documents/Document/Document/2376
I hope these help you out!
Jesse Himes, Knowledge Network Intern, jhimes@icma.org

author: Hallie Thompson
text: The San Diego Regional Water Quality Control Board has issued a new regional storm water (NPDES) permit.  One of the requirements of the permit is to inspect residential areas.  The City of Carlsbad has never formally inspected residential areas; only conducted outreach education and complaint response.  Are there other local jurisdictions that inspect/patrol residential areas for storm water regulation compliance and pollution prevention?
title: Residential storm water inspections
